enter.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to go or come into a place
enter.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Silence fell as I entered the room.
Few reporters dared to enter the war zone.
enter.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if an object enters part of something, it goes inside it
enter.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The bullet had entered his brain.
enter.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to start working in a particular profession or organization, or to start studying at a school or university
enter.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Both the boys entered the army.
He entered the Church (=became a priest) as a young man.
enter.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to start to take part in an activity, or become involved in a situation
enter.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: He entered the election as the clear favourite.
The rebels were prepared to enter negotiations (=start discussing something).
enter.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to put information into a computer by pressing the keys
enter.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Press the return key to enter the information.
The names are entered into a database.
enter.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: if you enter a computer system, you are given permission to use it by the computer
enter.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: It won’t let you enter without a password.
enter.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to write information on a particular part of a form, document etc
enter.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Don’t forget to enter your postcode.
Enter your name in the space provided.
enter.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to arrange to take part in a race, competition, examination etc, or to arrange for someone else to take part
enter.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: At least 30 schools entered the competition.
Decisions about when he or she is entered for an examination should be taken very carefully.
enter.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to begin a period of time when something happens
enter.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: The economy has entered a period of recession.
The talks have now entered their third week.
enter its third week/sixth day/second year etc
enter.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if a new idea, thought etc enters your head, or a new quality enters something, it suddenly starts to exist there
enter.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: A note of panic entered her voice.
It never entered his head that she might be seeing someone else.
enter.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: Wilson entered a plea of not guilty  (=said that he was not guilty at the beginning of a court case).
Residents entered a number of objections to the scheme.
enter.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: They entered the building through the front door
enter.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: You usually use enter into when talking about starting agreements or discussions with someone
enter.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: They went into the building through the front door
enter.translation[0].note_box[1].section: to go or come into a place. Enter is more formal than go in
It appears the burglars entered the house through a back window.
Occupying troops entered the town on 8th April.
go in/into something
to enter a place. Go in/into is the usual phrase to use in everyday English
It was getting cold so we went in.
He went into the cafe and ordered a drink.
come in/into something
to enter a place – used when you are already in that place
Come in and sit down.
When you come into the village, you’ll see the church on your right.
get in/into something
to succeed in entering a place, especially when it is difficult or it takes a long time
I’d lost my key so I couldn’t get in.
You can’t get into the club if you are under 18.
break in/into something
to enter a building using force, for example in order to steal something
If anyone tries to break in, the alarm will go off.
burst in/into something
to enter a room or building very suddenly and noisily
Two men with guns burst in and told us to lie on the floor.
He burst into my office laughing and screaming like a maniac.
barge in/into something
to suddenly enter a room where you are not wanted because you are interrupting someone or you were not invited
She just barged into my room without knocking.
You can’t just go barging in.
sneak in/into something
to enter a place quietly and secretly hoping that no one will notice you
If you’re late, just try and sneak into the back of the class.
slip in/into something
to enter a place quietly and quickly
Maggie opened the door silently and slipped in.
trespass
to enter an area of land that belongs to someone else without permission
The sign said ‘Trespassers will be prosecuted’.
Trespassing on the railway is a criminal offence in the UK.
enter.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if people or goods enter a country, they arrive there
enter.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: A lot of goods are fraudulently and illegally entering the US.
enter.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if a company enters a market, it starts selling goods or services in that market
enter.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The financial institution entered the Texas market last year by buying 20 failed banks.
Konica entered the underwater camera market with a basic model costing $8.95.
enter.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if a possible buyer enters a market, they start looking for something to buy there
enter.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Property prices soared as more young people entered the housing market.
enter.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: if someone enters a financial market, they buy or sell something there
enter.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Institutional investors repeatedly entered the market to sell as share prices rallied.
enter.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to write something in an account book, on a list etc
enter.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Any deposits received in advance are entered in the cash book.
enter.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to put information into a computer by pressing the KEYs
enter.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: If a command is entered incorrectly, the machine will not recognize it.
enter.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: The change to the law will protect customers who enter a contract as a result of doorstep canvassing.
enter.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: Britain’s agriculture industry could be plunged into crisis as fewer young people enter farming.
enter.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: to say that you are guilty or not guilty of a crime in a court of law
enter.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: He entered a plea of not guilty to the charge of causing death by reckless driving.
